description: From Middle English loupe (“opening in a wall”) +‎ hole, from a Germanic source. Compare Medieval Latin loupa, lobia and Middle Dutch lupen (“to watch”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A slit in a castle wall; today, any similar window for shooting a ranged weapon or letting in light. Also written loop hole.
examples: There was a loophole in this wall, to let the light in, just at the height of a person's head, who was sitting near the chimney.

entries.meaning: (figurative) A method of escape, especially an ambiguity or exception in a rule or law that can be exploited in order to avoid its effect.

verbs.description: loophole (third-person singular simple present loopholes, present participle loopholing, simple past and past participle loopholed)

entries.meaning: (military, transitive) To prepare a building for defense by preparing slits or holes through which to fire on attackers
(transitive) To exploit (a law, etc.) by means of loopholes.
examples: De-moralizing the subject can be, quite simply, demoralizing, as stirring statements of ideals turn into persnickety rules with exceptions crying out to be loopholed.
